## Our Question: What are the relationships between states and regions with regard to pregnancy health, income inequality, and access to justice across the US and how do these outcomes relate to federal spending?


## Indices Explored:

<ul>
<li><b>Gini Index</b> - Measures wealth inequality on a scale from 0 (complete equality) to 1 (complete inequality) as tabulated by the Census Bureau using the American Communities Survey, 2010.</li>
<li><b>Pregnancy Health </b>- To assess this, we use five measures selected by United Health Foundation from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and Guttmacher Institute to calculate a composite score for each state.</li>  
<li><b>The Justice Index </b>- Scores and ranks ability to protect rights in a state justice system by assessing whether a person can afford a lawyer, has language access, and can navigate the legal system with physical and/or mental disability.</li>  
<li><b>Federal Dependency </b>- A comparison of the amount of federal tax revenue generated by each state, versus the amount that state receives from the federal government at the individual and statewide levels.</li>  
</ul>

```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results='hide'}
library(lwgeom)
library(geojsonio)
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)
library(cowplot)
library(ggpubr)

#Rose's code for showing density plots and categorical lolliplots

#Step 1, bring in the data, create data frame
data <- read.csv("eardata.csv")
data <- as.data.frame(data)

#Step 2, create density plots for indicies with median line
Ginibase=ggplot(data,aes(x = Gini))+stat_density(geom = "line")+theme_classic()+labs(x='Inequality', y= NULL)+geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(Gini)),
            color="gray", linetype="dashed", size=.5)

Justicebase=ggplot(data,aes(x = JusticeIndex))+stat_density(geom = "line")+theme_classic()+labs(x='Justice', y= NULL)+geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(JusticeIndex)),
            color="gray", linetype="dashed", size=.5)

PHIbase=ggplot(data,aes(x = PHI))+stat_density(geom = "line")+theme_classic()+labs(x='Pregnancy Health', y= NULL)+geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(PHI)),
            color="gray", linetype="dashed", size=.5)

Dependencybase=ggplot(data,aes(x=DependencyScore))+stat_density(geom = "line")+theme_classic()+labs(x='Federal Dependency', y=NULL)+geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(DependencyScore)),
            color="gray", linetype="dashed", size=.5)

#Combining into one plot

DensityAll <-ggarrange(Ginibase,Justicebase,PHIbase,Dependencybase, ncol = 1,nrow = 4)

DensityAll2 = annotate_figure(DensityAll,
                            top = text_grob("Positive Skew for Justice, Pregnancy Health, and Federal Dependency",
                                            face = "bold", size = 11),
                            bottom = text_grob("Sources: ACS, 2010; National Center for Access to Justice, 2016; CDC, 2017; Guttmacher Institute, 2014; wallethub.com, 2019", 
                                               hjust = 1, x = 1,
                                               face = "italic", 
                                               size = 8),
                            left = 'Density',
                            right = NULL)

DensityAll2
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, results='hide'}
#Step 4, create lolliplots comparing Inequality and Pregnancy Health (most intersting comparisons)

#Create data frame - Inequality
summary(data$Gini)
data$GiniGroup =cut(data$Gini,
                          breaks = c(0.4,0.452,0.4673,0.4789,0.53),
                          #labels = c("1st Quartile","2nd Quartile","3rd Quartile", "4th Quartile"))
                          labels = c("Low"," ","  ","High"))

#marginal data frame - Inequality 
(GiniRegion=table(data$GiniGroup,data$Region))

GiniRegion_mgcol=prop.table(GiniRegion,
                              margin = 2)

GiniRegion_df<-as.data.frame(GiniRegion)
names(GiniRegion_df)
names(GiniRegion_df)<-c("GiniGroup","Region","Count")

GiniRegion_df$pctCol=as.data.frame(GiniRegion_mgcol)[,3]
head(GiniRegion_df)

#Create data frame - Pregnancy Health
summary(data$PHI)
data$PHIGroup =cut(data$PHI,
                          breaks = c(0.17,0.2062,0.2273,0.2541,0.33),
                          #labels = c("1st Quartile","2nd Quartile","3rd Quartile", "4th Quartile"))
                          labels = c("Low"," ","  ", "High"))

#marginal data frame - Pregnancy Health
(PHIRegion=table(data$PHIGroup,data$Region))

PHIRegion_mgcol=prop.table(PHIRegion,
                              margin = 2)

PHIRegion_df<-as.data.frame(PHIRegion)
names(PHIRegion_df)
names(PHIRegion_df)<-c("PHIGroup","Region","Count")

PHIRegion_df$pctCol=as.data.frame(PHIRegion_mgcol)[,3]
head(PHIRegion_df)

#Create lolliplot - Inequality
lolliplotGini = 
  ggplot(GiniRegion_df, 
                 aes(x = GiniGroup,
                     y = pctCol) ) + 
  geom_segment(aes(y = 0,
                   x = GiniGroup,  
                   yend = pctCol, #ends at the pct value
                   xend = GiniGroup)) + facet_grid( ~ Region) +
  geom_point()+theme_bw()+
  labs(y= "Inequality", 
       x=NULL)+ylim(0, .9)

#Create lolloplot - Pregnancy Health
lolliplotPHI = 
  ggplot(PHIRegion_df, 
                 aes(x = PHIGroup,
                     y = pctCol) ) + 
  geom_segment(aes(y = 0,
                   x = PHIGroup,  
                   yend = pctCol, #ends at the pct value
                   xend = PHIGroup)) + facet_grid( ~ Region) +
  geom_point()+theme_bw()+
  labs(y= "Pregnancy Health", 
       x=NULL)+ylim(0, .9)

#Group and label two plots
LolliAll_1 <-ggarrange(lolliplotGini,lolliplotPHI, ncol = 1,nrow = 2)

LolliAll_2= annotate_figure (LolliAll_1,
                            top = text_grob("Pregnancy Health Best in Northeast, High Inequality and Low Pregnancy Health in South",
                                            face = "bold", size = 11),
                            bottom = text_grob("Sources: ACS, 2010; CDC, 2017; Guttmacher Institute, 2014", 
                                               hjust = 1, x = 1,
                                               face = "italic", 
                                               size = 8))

LolliAll_2
```

```{r include=FALSE, results='hide'}
#create super index by normalizing, getting on a 0-1 scale, and combining all 3 variables of interest

summary(total$JusticeIndex)
#divide by 100 to get on a 0-1 scale
total$newjustice<-(total$JusticeIndex/100)

#subtract mean
summary(total$newjustice)
total$newjustice<-(total$newjustice-.3926)

#divide by SD
sd(total$newjustice)
total$newjustice <-(total$newjustice/.112602)

#a more-normally-distributed variable:
summary(total$newjustice)

#all positive values
total$newjustice <-(total$newjustice+2.1807253)
#0-1 scale
total$newjustice <-(total$newjustice/5)

#subtract mean
summary(total$Gini)
total$newgini<-(total$Gini-.4646)

#divide by SD
sd(total$newgini)
total$newgini <-(total$newgini/.02101533)

#a more-normally-distributed variable:
summary(total$newgini)
#all positive values
total$newgini <-(total$newgini+2.774167)
#0-1 scale
total$newgini <-(total$newgini/5.6)

#subtract mean
summary(total$PHI)
total$newphi<-(total$PHI-.2324)

#divide by SD
sd(total$newphi)
total$newphi <-(total$newphi/0.03823467)

#a more-normally-distributed variable:
summary(total$newphi)
#all positive values
total$newphi <-(total$newphi+1.5535638)
#0-1 scale
total$newphi <-(total$newphi/5)


#CREATE SUPER INDEX

total$superindex<- total$newphi+total$newjustice-total$newgini
summary(total$superindex)
```


```{r include=FALSE, results='hide'}

# cut the index and the federal dependency and the combination of both into "better and worse" groups

total$superindexhighlow =cut(total$superindex,
                          breaks = c(-0.47584,0.18394,1.04287),
                          labels = c("Worse","Better"))

summary(total$superindexhighlow)

summary(total$DependencyScore)
total$federaldependencyhighlow = cut(total$DependencyScore, 
                               breaks = c(10.6,37.77,85.82),
                               labels = c("Better","Worse"))

summary(total$federaldependencyhighlow)
summary(total$superindexhighlow)

# create a combination of super index and federal dependency for the map: better, worse, and mixed

total$goodbad <- ifelse(total$federaldependencyhighlow == "Worse" & total$superindexhighlow == "Worse", "Worse", ifelse(total$federaldependencyhighlow == "Better" & total$superindexhighlow == "Better", "Better", "Mixed"))

summary(total$goodbad)
total$goodbad

```

## Conclusions:
 
<p>Comparing <b>between states</b>, social outcomes such as pregnancy health and access to justice are positively correlated, and as inequality increases, pregnancy health goes down. Thus, states that tend to value a social outcome like health also tend to value justice and equality.</p>
<p>At a <b>regional level</b>, the Midwest and the West have mixed outcomes. The Northeast has higher inequality but the best pregnancy health, and the South stands out as a region with poorer social outcomes. </p>
<p>Comparing the social outcomes together as a <b>“Super-Index”</b>, we see that states in the central band from California to Michigan and the Northeast fare best. This is correlated with low federal dependency in the California-Michigan band. Poor social outcomes and high federal dependency are both characteristic for the South.</p>


## A Note:

<p>Our findings of worse outcomes in the South cannot be considered outside the context of US history. The making of American capitalism and prosperity was based largely on extracting wealth from slave labor in the South through a system of violence and oppression. Slavery enriched the US financial system, was a key driver of national economic growth, and fueled the industrial revolution in the North. Thus, as we compare between regions and states, we acknowledge that these maps tell a deeper story about the legacy of slavery and our racially structured economy and society. At large, the US has yet to transform its institutions in order to provide all Americans with equal access to health care, justice, and other measures of social well-being.</p>
